Advokat John Christian Elden tok opp en feiltolkning av EÃ˜S-regelverket for HÃ¸yesterett i 2017. Han ble ikke hÃ¸rt i saken.
04 Nov 2019, 06:21 by NTB



John Christian Elden prÃ¸vde Ã¥ ta opp en feiltolkning av EÃ˜S-regelverket i HÃ¸yesterett i 2017. Han sier retten ikke ville behandle spÃ¸rsmÃ¥let. ğŸ“· Foto: Ole Berg-Rusten / NTB scanpix Galleri



I en juridisk vurdering fra Nav heter det at etaten mener norsk lov ikke var i strid med EÃ˜S-retten fÃ¸r den nye trygdeforordningen trÃ¥dte i kraft i 2012. ğŸ“· Illustrasjonsfoto: Berit Roald / NTB scanpix Galleri


De aller fleste av de 48 bedrageridommene som er identifisert i trygdeskandalen, er kun behandlet i tingretten. Ã‰n av sakene gikk helt til HÃ¸yesterett i avdeling, skriver Rett24.
I saken fra 2016 ble en mann i 60-Ã¥rene dÃ¸mt til 75 dagers ubetinget fengsel i Nedre Telemark tingrett. Mannen hadde flere ganger reist til Italia mens han mottok arbeidsavklaringspenger (AAP).
Saken ble anket til lagmannsretten, og straffen ble omgjort til samfunnsstraff. Nav anket straffeutmÃ¥lingen til HÃ¸yesterett.
Elden var forsvarer for mannen og har gÃ¥tt gjennom papirene fra saken pÃ¥ nytt. Han har funnet at han anfÃ¸rte EÃ˜S-avtalen og trygdeforordningen fra 2012 da saken var til behandling. Elden sier til Rett24 at han fikk beskjed om at dette var utenfor anken.
HÃ¸yesterett skulle i saken ikke ta stilling til saksbehandlingsfeil, men selve straffeutmÃ¥lingen. Elden mente likevel at feiltolkningen var avgjÃ¸rende for om mannen skulle dÃ¸mmes til fengsel eller samfunnsstraff.
â€“ Retten ville ikke diskutere denne problematikken. Jeg fikk beskjed om at det ikke var tema, sier Elden til VG.
HÃ¸yesterettsjustitiarius Toril Marie Ã˜ie administrerte saken. Hun sier til avisen at hun ikke kan kommentere straffeutmÃ¥lingen.
I en juridisk vurdering fra Nav heter det at etaten mener norsk lov ikke var i strid med EÃ˜S-retten fÃ¸r den nye trygdeforordningen trÃ¥dte i kraft i 2012.
text:
Lawyer Elden led Nav failure to Supreme Court without result
Lawyer John Christian Elden misinterpreted the EEA rules of the Supreme Court in 2017. He was not heard in the case.
04 Nov 2019, 06:21 by NTB



John Christian Elden tried to raise a misinterpretation of the EEA regulations in the Supreme Court in 2017. He says the court would not address the issue. ğŸ“· Photo: Ole Berg-Rusten / NTB scanpix Gallery



A legal assessment from Nav states that the agency believes Norwegian law was not in breach of EEA law until the new social security regulation came into force in 2012. ğŸ“· Illustrative photo: Berit Roald / NTB scanpix Gallery


The vast majority of the 48 fraud cases identified in the Social Security scandal have only been dealt with in the District Court. One of the cases went all the way to the Supreme Court in the department, writes Rett24.
In the 2016 case, a man in his 60s was sentenced to 75 days unconditional imprisonment in the Lower Telemark District Court. The man had traveled to Italy several times while receiving work clearance money (AAP).
The case was appealed to the Court of Appeal, and the penalty was turned into a social penalty. Nav appealed the sentencing to the Supreme Court.
Elden was the defender for the man and has gone through the papers from the case again. He has found that he cited the EEA Agreement and the Social Security Ordinance from 2012 when the matter was pending. The elder tells Rett24 that he was told that this was outside the appeal.
In the case, the Supreme Court should not decide on procedural errors, but the actual sentencing. The elder nevertheless felt that the misinterpretation was crucial to whether the man should be sentenced to prison or community punishment.
- The court would not discuss this issue. I was told that it was not a theme, says Elden to VG.
Supreme Court Justice Toril Marie Ã˜ie administered the case. She tells the newspaper that she cannot comment on the sentencing.
A legal assessment from Nav states that the agency believes that Norwegian law was not in breach of EEA law until the new social security regulation came into force in 2012.
